subject: Re: [junit] Test Everything, No Matter How Simple
msgSnippet: ... Aha. I withdraw my objection and resolve to watch more British comedies. I should have Blackadder around here somewhere.... -- J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger ::
messageBody:
Simon Chappell wrote:

> On 8/22/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...
> <mailto:cbeust%40google.com>> wrote:
> > On 8/22/06, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...
> <mailto:simonpeterchappell%40gmail.com>> wrote:
> > >
> > > > So you're recommending 100% code coverage?
> > >
> > > So you're recommending 0% code coverage?
> >
> > Can you explain how you deduce this from my asking for a simple
> > clarification about the article?
>
> It's my dry British humour. You take a statement about testing
> everything and ask if that means he's recommending 100% code coverage;
> "everything" generally means 100%. So, I applied humour by absurdity
> and asked if you were recommending 0% coverage, that being the exact
> opposite thing.

Aha. I withdraw my objection and resolve to watch more British comedies.
I should have Blackadder around here somewhere....
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
